Award.AwardTitle: Silicon Valley Innovation & Entrepreneurship Scholarshops (SVIES) Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This National Science Foundation (NSF) Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) project at San Jose State University in San Jose, California will provide scholarships and support services to academically-talented students pursing graduate engineering degrees who demonstrate financial need. This project called the Silicon Valley Innovation and Entrepreneurship Scholarships (SVIES) Program will provide graduate students of the College of Engineering with opportunities to learn about innovation and entrepreneurship, equips them with methods facilitating innovation, and matches them with Silicon Valley innovators and entrepreneurs as mentors. Entrepreneurship and innovation are critical factors in a thriving economy. This project will develop entrepreneurial skills in engineering students from financially disadvantaged backgrounds. The program will expand the career options of talented low-income engineering students who may have otherwise been unfamiliar with opportunities and methods of technological entrepreneurism and innovation.

The goal of the San Jose State University (SJSU) Silicon Valley Innovation and Entrepreneurship Scholarships Program is to increase the nation's capacity to produce technological innovations that drive economic growth. The scholarship recipients will form a learning community and engage in joint study of successful Silicon Valley technological innovations and entrepreneurs and in team practice of the lessons learned. With direct mentoring from Silicon Valley innovators and entrepreneurs and seven SJSU College of Engineering faculty members, SVIES scholars will develop their innovation mindsets, acquire innovation and entrepreneurship skills, and have the opportunity to incorporate innovation and entrepreneurship into their career plans. The project will help talented engineering students from low-income backgrounds to become effective technological entrepreneurs. Evaluation and assessment will focus on measuring and documenting learning outcomes in high-level competencies associated with innovation and entrepreneurism. These outcomes include: the mindset of innovation and entrepreneurship, knowledge of the need-idea-venture process, and ability to innovate, create and refine a technological invention; develop a business plan and launch a new business venture. Lessons learned and best practices that emerge from the program evaluation data will be disseminated widely to the engineering education community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Before proposing this Program, the PI and co-PI were not researchers about innovation education or even about engineering education. We were educators believing that innovation education would be critically important for the nation and for the world; we were also researchers conducting research in conventional academic disciplines but also having product/service ideas that had the potential to change how people live or work. We have been passionate about innovation education not only as educators but also as prospective start-up founders. This Program does not have any coursework associated with it, and our goal had been to develop mindset, provide knowledge and equip ability of innovation and entrepreneurship for the recipients, all in a most effective and efficient manner. We developed the Program to help achieve this goal; in the process, we have also learned about innovation and entrepreneurship, perhaps even more so than the recipients. We shared our lessons learned at the 2019 S-STEM Symposium (9/12/2019 - 9/14/2019) by conducting a 75-minute workshop.  These lessons can help 'scale up' urgently needed innovation education effectively and efficiently, without a traditional college course.

The SVIES Program had provided all the recipients with training activities to develop their innovation mindset, to provide them with knowledge about innovation and entrepreneurship and to equip them with the ability to be innovative and entrepreneurial. Innovation is encouraged for all engineering professionals, whether they ever wish to engage in entrepreneurial activities, e.g., founding a start-up company, or not.  While the management team is confident that all the recipients would be innovative in their careers, only time can tell if some of the recipients will become entrepreneurs and found start-up companies.

In each of the four academic years, the recipients received an orientation on fundamentals of innovation and entrepreneurship, with real Silicon Valley I&E histories. It was followed by a boot camp, featuring one or more serial entrepreneurs of the Silicon Valley, e.g., Regis McKenna. All recipients were encouraged to develop an innovation history about an innovative product or service, preferably one that was developed in the Silicon Valley. A workshop followed, and they were encouraged to report and improve on their innovation histories. The workshop was then followed by one or more visits with a Silicon Valley innovation incubator or accelerator. Except for the first year, we visited an accelerator that allowed us to observe a 2.5-hour live pitch session consisting of 10-minute investment ?pitches? by about one dozen start-up teams to investors affiliated with the accelerator. The session was preceded by a facility tour and followed by a one-hour networking lunch with the presenting start-up teams and investor judges. The recipients also attended activities recommended by the SVIES management team, e.g., the Revolutionaries series of speaker events sponsored by the Computer History Museum located in the city of Mountain View in the Silicon Valley. 

This Program had provided scholarships to 49 recipients in the 2015 ? 2019 academic years, totaling $520K. 38 of them have graduated. Some of the rest have only MS Thesis or Project to complete graduation; some others are on their way to graduation in the near future. Yet, some others decided to take a leave of absence to work in the Silicon Valley or elsewhere. We had made the application and evaluation process transparent in that we did not provide to the evaluators any data about any applicant that contained or could be used to infer the gender, ethnic group, nationality and other aspects that are not relevant to academic or innovation/entrepreneurial activities. Three of the graduates went on to study for their Ph.D. at University of California campuses.  They are an African American, a Latino and a Caucasian. Among the 49, five are African Americans; four are Latino/Latina; 18 are females. Among the 49, three had BA degrees, made up curricular deficiencies and graduated with an engineering MS degree.
